references: In this section, we introduce the key notations and technical terms essential for GNN backdoor implementations, which are shown in Tab. 1 and Tab. 2 respectively.

S1.T2.caption: Table 2. Technical Terms
S1.T2.table:
Terms Definitions and Descriptions
Benign model The model trained under benign settings.
Infected model The model with hidden backdoor(s).
Poisoned sample The modified training sample used in poisoning-based backdoor attacks for embedding backdoor(s) in the model during the training process.
Trigger The pattern used for generating poisoned samples and activating the hidden backdoor(s).
Attacked sample The malicious testing sample containing backdoor trigger(s).
Source label The ground-truth label of a poisoned or an attacked sample.
Target label The attacker-specified label.
Attacker’s goal What the backdoor attacker intends to do.
Capacity What the attacker/defender can and cannot do to achieve their goal.
references: In this section, we introduce the key notations and technical terms essential for GNN backdoor implementations, which are shown in Tab. 1 and Tab. 2 respectively.

references: Based on the classification of backdoor attacks studies on GNN outlined at the beginning of this section, we will elaborate on them in two parts: (i) adaptability-expanding research; (ii) effectiveness-improving research. The comprehensive summary of backdoor attacks is shown in Tab. 3.

references: In response to the threat of GNN backdoor attacks, researchers have begun focusing on developing effective defense strategies. The comprehensive summary of GNN backdoor defense studies is displayed in Tab. 4.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5. Summary of Future Directions for Graph Neural Backdoors
S5.T5.table:
Direction Research Focus Specific Topic
Backdoor optimization Graph semantic backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Adaptive trigger-optimization ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Hide semantic features of trigger
Black-box graph backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Inverse engineering-based approach ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Surrogate model-based data-poisoning
Dormant Graph Backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To make GNN backdoor triggerable only after downstream fine-tuning
Untargeted graph backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To implant target-unspecified graph neural backdoors
Applicability extension Generative graph backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To implant backdoor into generative graph neural models
Few-shot graph backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To implant backdoor into few-shot-based GNN models
Graph large language model backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Fine-tuning backdoor embedding ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Distributed backdoor embedding ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Data augmentation backdoor embedding ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Multi-modal Graph backdoor embedding
Parameter modification backdoor ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To backdoor GNN through model modification without data-poisoning
Countermeasure Development Black-box graph backdoor detection ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To detect GNN backdoor without available model info. or graphs
Black-box graph backdoor mitigation ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To erase implanted backdoor without available model info. or graphs
Graph backdoor explainability ⋄⋄\diamond⋄ To develop explainability tools and algorithms for GNN backdoors
references: A brief summary for the future directions of GNN backdoor is shown in Tab. 5.
